Another funny Egyptian joke, no where in the world is there such a thing, and the guys who started this idea wanted to do it to "prevent" those without a degree (I have a degree btw) from becoming software engineers. There was one guy who looked and dressed like Abdel Halim Hafiz and he told me that I have no right to take his job :) :) :)

In south Africa, for me to start working I had to get IITPSA, so I think it's normal to have something like that
Link: http://www.iitpsa.org.za/
Anyway I am a member of the Engineering Syndicate and for some reason "because I know we're Psyco" will sue as usual and screw thy project.

South Africa is a great place, but not always a role model for management. It is essentially a job without a degree, the degree was an afterthought, they had degrees because universities wanted to create degrees so students could be employable. You can be a software engineer actually with minimal formal education, just reading and writing but an "understanding" of the concepts which I have seen A+ students who can't grasp them. And the last thing Egypt needs is a barrier of entry for engineers. I think the real barrier of entry should be at the management levels since we seem to be failing miserably at producing a critical mass of "good" managers.

The graveyard of talent .. As usual
BTW this is exactly the same reason I hate when people specify that this group is elite, if you view yourself as elite, you have a lot to learn...
